subject: Re: [junit] Programmer Tests and the Database
msgSnippet: ... Yes, that is the point of my tests, too. ... Well, true...but how you get away with not changing the SQL for long periods is beyond me. I ve never done
messageBody:
On Sun, 9 Feb 2003, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> Remember that part of the point of these tests is to enable me to make
> changes and see the consequences of those things. That way I am
> aggressive and make changes without fear of unknowingly breaking some
> part of the system.

Yes, that is the point of my tests, too.

> If I don't change the DBMS nor the operating environment, then the SQL
> statements, once correct, cannot break. They become a "golden master"
> against which I can continue to compare as needed.

Well, true...but how you get away with not changing the SQL for long
periods is beyond me. I've never done serious develoment on a system
with a lot of database code where the database wasn't changing all the
time. But we probably just tend to work on different styles of projects.

> Better would be to have some in-memory SQL syntax/semantics checker
> that worked against my database schema, simulated the statements and
> ensured that they continue to make sense.

No, this to my mind would be a complete waste of time. If you haven't
changed the statements, you don't need to syntax check them, even, as
you pointed out. Just return the data the statement is supposed to return
and leave it at that.

If you do change the statements, and you're not checking them against
the database, you're going to need an *extremely* thorough and accurate
simulation of the database software. Given the huge complexity of quirks
of most RDBMSs, that would be extraordinally expensive and difficult.
Why not just use the most accurate simulation, the database itself?

> But like I said, if I move all the SQL statements into one place, I can
> easily write a simple test to verify those statements against the
> database. I can run that test less frequently, thus avoiding the
> overhead of running them all the time.

There is no need to have all your statements separated from the code that
uses them in order to test separately. I'm sure you can come up with many
other ways to turn on and off individual tests.
